data.title: Many undos + Many redos freezes VS Code
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.6.1
- OS Version: Win 10

Steps to Reproduce:
1.  Use VS Code for hours
2.  Realize you accidentally deleted something, undo (ctrl+z) a lot to try and find it (probably a few dozen undos)
3.  Redo (ctrl+y) a lot to get back to the present

Expected: Everything is fine
Actual: VSCode stalled and had to be restarted

data.title: Allow debug adapters to customize the behavior of the 'restart' button
data.body: For the chrome debugging extension, it would be much more useful if the debug 'restart' button/action could refresh the page. This could be implemented by the debug adapter. For other cases, the current behavior should be kept where vscode shuts down/restarts the debug adapter. Is this generic enough to be part of the debug protocol?

data.title: Request: TextDocumentWillOpenEvent
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.6.1 
- OS Version: macOS 10.12

Since Visual Studio Code will not open binary files (for good reasons, mostly), I was wondering if you'd consider adding something like`TextDocumentWillOpenEvent`, an event that fires before the file is opened. This would be useful for decoding a file so it _can_ be opened.

data.title: Stopping or restarting node.js debugger crashes vscode
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.6.1
- OS Version: OSX El Capitan 10.11.6
- Node version: 6.7.0

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Start vscode through the finder
2. Open a new folder
3. Create a new file app.js in the root of the folder with contents

```
var msg = 'hello world'
console.log(msg)
```
1. [optional] Confirm that "hello world" is printed when running the file with
   `node app.js`
2. Click the gear in the DEBUG pane to create a Node.js launch.json config.
3. Hit F5 or click the run button to run app.js with the debugger attached
   Expected behavior: "hello world" is printed to the console. No breakpoints are set, so the program runs and terminates, and the debugger detaches automatically.
   Actual behavior: "hello world" is printed to the console. The debugger stays attached.
4. Hit Shift-F5 or the Stop Debugging button to detach the debugger and terminate the node program.
   Expected behavior: The debugger detaches and vscode exits debug mode.
   **Actual behavior: Nothing happens for about 10 seconds, then vscode crashes.**

_Possible clue_ 
If vscode was launched from the command line with 
`code`
(see the shell command setup here https://code.visualstudio.com/docs/setup/mac)
Then step 7 produces the following output in the debug console, and vscode does not crash.

```
/usr/local/Cellar/node/6.7.0/bin/node[57339]: ../src/debug-agent.cc:149:void node::debugger::Agent::Stop(): Assertion `(err) == (0)' failed.
 1: node::Abort() [/usr/local/bin/node]
 2: node::RunMicrotasks(v8::FunctionCallbackInfo<v8::Value> const&) [/usr/local/bin/node]
 3: node::debugger::Agent::~Agent() [/usr/local/bin/node]
 4: node::debugger::Agent::~Agent() [/usr/local/bin/node]
 5: node::Environment::~Environment() [/usr/local/bin/node]
 6: node::Start(int, char**) [/usr/local/bin/node]
 7: start [/usr/local/bin/node]
```

data.title: Buffer untitled/text file model changed events and make the event type consistent
data.body:
From @bpasero in https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/pull/14115#discussion_r84486381

> I see the need for an event when untitled or text files are changing so that the backup service can do its business, however I fear that this comes at the cost of spam: you will see many model content change events while the user is typing, so basically each key press will trigger this event. Performance should always be something to be concerned of, especially when it is typing performance we are talking about.
> 
> Some ideas:
> 
> buffer the model content change event and only start to emit the change after a certain delay
> do not always create an event object to send around
> I think buffering would be a good idea anyway because backups should also not be created without some delay.

From @bpasero  in https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/pull/14115#discussion_r87146511

> @Tyriar I do not see a reason to create an object here each time a character is typed. the untitled event just sends around its resource URI and I would do the same thing here for files.
>
> Cannot say it often enough, this model content change event WILL FIRE like CRAZY. And perf is a hot topic after hot exit :)

data.title: The app opens then immediately closes without displaying any error
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.7.0-insider
  69fe34632fa4651e89db040fb205f0c739598197
- OS Version: macOS Sierra
  Version 10.12

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Double click the `Visual Studio Code - Insiders.app` in the Applications folder to start the app per usual.

Expected Behavior:
The application opens and I can edit files.

Actual Behavior:
The application immediately closes without warning or displaying an error.

Attempted remediation steps:
1. Reinstalling the application has no effect
2. I have removed the directories `~/Library/Caches/com.microsoft.VSCodeInsiders` and `~/Library/Caches/com.microsoft.VSCodeInsiders.ShipIt`
3. `code --disable-extensions` does not open the app

No remediation steps have had any effect. The app simply will not open.

Additional Information:
1. The stable version runs without issue: v1.6.1
   9e4e44c19e393803e2b05fe2323cf4ed7e36880e
2. `code --disable-extensions --disable-gpu -w` returns almost immediately.
3. What led to this? Honestly have no idea. I have not been working on any large projects or things that have been giving the application fits. This problem started today after running successfully for many weeks. I upgraded to macOS Sierra approximately two weeks ago without issue.

data.title: Better visual indication that a task is currently running
data.body:
If you execute a task, the only indication that anything is running is a small spinner in the bottom left of the screen that doesn't catch someone's attention easily. So sometimes you think a process is still running only to look down there and realize the process ended a while ago.

A better visual indication would be useful. For example, change the color of the output window title bar (the bar that says 'OUTPUT'), to a color that can be configured in user settings.

Then it's easy to tell that something isn't running because the title bar color has gone back to normal.

data.title: ! completion adding extra characters at end
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.7
- OS Version: OS X 10.11.6

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Open terminal
2. Type `git rebase --continue` and enter
3. `!git re<Tab>`
4. Expected `git rebase --continue` to show, but instead `git rebase --continue re` is shown.

data.title: Output not respecting overwriting lines (process.stdout.write with \r)
data.body:
If you run this code in a regular terminal then value1 will be overwritten by value2 which will be overwritten by value3, as expected. But if you run it in vscode, the output window shows value1, value2, and value3 on their own lines, which doesn't respect the expected `\r` behavior.

```
process.stdout.write(`value1\r`)
process.stdout.write(`value2\r`)
process.stdout.write(`value3\r`)
```

based on the final example in screenshot above, it seems like region tagging isn't even working, and just seems to be working due to VSCode's default settings

data.title: VsCode's Task.json and Gulp doesn't pass arguments correctly
data.body:
**Versions**
- VSCode Version: 1.6.1
- OS Version: Windows 10

**Problem**
Passing values from VsCode, like the current file, is not possible when using Task.json and Gulpfile.js

**Why**
Task.js offers arguments, but in a not in the right order. For example:

```
{ 
 "command": "gulp"
  "args": ["myCommandArguments"],
  "tasks" : [ 
    { "taskName": "myTaskThatDoesSomethingForTheActiveFile",
      "args": ["myTaskArguments"],
      "suppressTaskName": false,
    }
  ]
}
```

This will end up doing : 

```
gulp myCommandArguments myTaskArguments myTaskThatDoesSomethingForTheActiveFile
```

As you can see the `myTashARguments` is not after the gulp task, hence cannot be read by gulp

**Other links that share the same issue:**
http://stackoverflow.com/questions/33348654/pass-arguments-to-gulpfile-task-from-tasks-json
http://stackoverflow.com/a/30419250/13913

data.title: Test: multi target debugging
data.body:
Test for #13426:
Complexity: 5
- [x] Windows - @joaomoreno
- [x] OS X - @weinand (incl. multi threaded program)
- [x] Linux - @roblourens 

We have introduced multi target debugging as described here https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/13426
Because this required a big refactoring of the debug model, first have a regular debug configuration and verify as many debug features as possible. This includes:
- Variables view updates as a focused stack frame is changed and all the variable actions work as expected
- Watch expression view updates as a focused stack frame is changed and you can add / edit watch expressions
- Callstack view nicely shows the callstack - at least one tester should try debugging a multi threaded program (@weinand debugged multi threaded mono program).
- Breakpoint view - enabling, disabling, adding breakpoints works as expected
- Floating debug action widget
- Debug repl evaluates as excepted and you get suggestions in the debg repl input

You do not have to cover each and every of these features, just try to be creative and test as many actions as time allows.

In order to enable multi target debugging, you need to add an `composite` configuration in your `'launch.json'` as described in https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/13426
Verify:
- Multiple debug processes get started and this is properly displayed in the call stack view
- You can switch between processes by clicking on the callstack and all the actions are performed on the selected process
- Once a breakpoint is hit on a process that process automtically get selected

data.title: Error when replacing text quickly
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.6.1
- OS Version: Windows 10 Enterprise version 1607

Steps to Reproduce:
- Open a new file.
- Write "I like fine wine."
- Open search.
  - Search for "i".
  - Replace with "aye".
  - Leave other options blank.
- Hit enter.
- Open the "foo.txt" section that appears below.
- Click on the first result. (There are 4, one for each "i" in the source text.)
- Hover over the "replace" button that appears.
- Click twice quickly.

Expected: "aye layeke fine wine."; got: "ayeayelike fine wine."
The error does not happen if clicking slowly.

data.title: PHP syntax highlighting without <?php

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
VS Code currently highlights something that has the language ID `php` only if it is wrapped in `<?php` tags, and everything outside like HTML. That is wrong in a few ways. The code outside of `<?php` is not "php" language, it is whatever output you are using. So for a CLI application, code outside would just get printed to STDOUT, while in a webserver it would get send to the client, which means the language is dependend on the `Content-Type` header (it does not have to be text/html). Only the code _inside_ `<?php` tags should be considered PHP, the outside can actually be any language, like `html` or `plaintext`. As this is not defined anywhere, VS Code should autodetect and fallback to HTML as that is most used. The inside is then "injected" as PHP like JavaScript in a `<script/>` tag or CSS in a `<style/>` tag. Also see #1751.

This causes many issues:
1. PHP in markdown blocks don't get highlighted if they use the ```php tag and do not contain `<?php`. If you switch to preview or view the file on GitHub or any other editor, everything works fine.  
   ![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/10532611/19602026/df226f72-97ab-11e6-83d8-8867cfe52089.png)
2. If you `eval()` to evaluate code (which does not require `<?php` tags) and the PHP debugger breaks inside that code, VS Code does a `sourceRequest`. The reported code does not get syntax highlighted. This means the PHP debugger [needs to dynamically add this tag](https://github.com/felixfbecker/vscode-php-debug/blob/master/src/phpDebug.ts#L589), which also means that every breakpoint request, every stackframe location [needs to be shifted one line down](https://github.com/felixfbecker/vscode-php-debug/blob/master/src/phpDebug.ts#L539).
3. Like many language servers, [the PHP LS includes a declaration line in the HoverResponse](https://github.com/felixfbecker/php-language-server/pull/50). This declaration line is only colored if a `<?php` is included, which I would like to remove because it doesn't make sense: I declared the language to be PHP, so it should be highlighted as PHP. Other clients like Eclipse behave correctly here. Issue: https://github.com/felixfbecker/php-language-server/issues/105  
   ![hover](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/10532611/19514022/5b6a20cc-95f2-11e6-8e32-0f22857b3def.png)

data.title: Feature request: configure tooltip max width
data.body: When you hover over a type in a TypeScript file, the tooltip that appears has a very low max width, making it difficult to read long type signatures.

data.title: Attempting to open a file from the commandline (or via git editor) fails to open file
data.body:
- VSCode Version: `Version 1.7.0-insider (1.7.0-insider)` 69fe34632fa4651e89db040fb205f0c739598197
- OS Version: `macOS Sierra 10.12 (16A323)`

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Try opening a file from the command line `code foobar.md`
2. Almost all of the time it will open code without any file at all (it worked once)

Or
1. Using code as your git editor have git open the editor (via commit or interactive rebase)
2. Almost all of the time code will open blank

This is a regression in 69fe34632fa4651e89db040fb205f0c739598197 as yesterday's build worked fine.

data.title: Feature request: jump to relative line number

milestone.title: Backlog
